name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). Consider edge cases where the array is too small or all elements are identical. Make sure to handle arrays with fewer than three elements gracefully. Ensure to check for scenarios where deleting any pairing might disrupt the intended mean.

Monocarp has an array a consisting of n integers. The average, denoted as k, is calculated by summing all the elements and dividing by the number of elements (n). This average can be a non-integer value.

Monocarp wants to remove exactly two elements from the array a such that the average of the remaining (n - 2) elements remains the same as k.

The average of an array is found by summing all its elements and dividing by the number of elements. Monocarp aims to delete two elements from the array to ensure the average of the remaining elements is still k.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

4

Output

Note

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

Monocarp has an array a of n integers. The mean k of these elements is calculated. He wants to remove two elements so that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements equals k. Find the number of pairs [i, j] (i < j) where removing elements at these positions keeps the mean of the array unchanged. Handle edge cases and arrays with fewer than three elements.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin
completions:
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(arr: List[int], mean: float) -> int:
    n = len(arr)
    count = 0

    # Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of elements at indices i and j
            sum_ij = arr[i] + arr[j]
            # Check if the sum of elements at indices i and j is equal to the original mean multiplied by 2
            if sum_ij == 2 * mean:
                count += 1

    return count

# Read input
n = int(input())
arr = list(map(int, input().split()))

# Calculate the mean of the array
mean = sum(arr) / n

# Call the function and print the result
result = calculate_pairs(arr, mean)
print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs_to_delete(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    if all(x == arr[0] for x in arr):
        return 0
    
    mean_value = sum(arr) / n
    
    pairs_to_delete = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            temp_arr = arr[:i] + arr[i+1:j] + arr[j+1:]
            if sum(temp_arr) / (n - 2) == mean_value:
                pairs_to_delete += 1
    
    return pairs_to_delete

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs_to_delete(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            new_n = n - 2
            if new_sum / new_n == mean:
                count += 1
    return count

# Provide the Interface
n = int(input())
arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    average = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    diff_count = {}
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            remaining_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            if remaining_sum / (n - 2) == average:
                count += 1
                diff = remaining_sum - (average * (n - 2))
                if diff in diff_count:
                    count += diff_count[diff]
                    diff_count[diff] += 1
                else:
                    diff_count[diff] = 1
    return count

# Interface
n = int(input())
arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
print(result)

from typing import List
from typing import List

def find_pairs_to_remove(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    original_mean = total_sum / n
    
    pairs_to_remove = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
                if new_mean == original_mean:
                    pairs_to_remove += 1
    
    return pairs_to_remove

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs_to_remove(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def find_pairs_to_remove(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    pairs_to_remove = 0
    
    # Create a dictionary to count occurrences of each element
    element_count = {}
    for num in arr:
        element_count[num] = element_count.get(num, 0) + 1
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                # Calculate the sum of the remaining elements after removing arr[i] and arr[j]
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                # Check if the new mean is still the same
                if new_sum / (n - 2) == mean:
                    pairs_to_remove += 1
    
    return pairs_to_remove

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs_to_remove(n, arr)
    print(result)

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):

                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)

requirement analysis:
The primary requirement is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean of the remaining elements unchanged. This involves summing the elements, calculating the mean, and then checking pairs to ensure their deletion does not alter the mean. The solution must handle edge cases and large inputs efficiently.
requirement pool:
- Implement a function to calculate the mean of the array.
- Create a function to iterate through pairs of positions and check if deleting them keeps the mean unchanged.
- Optimize the solution for large inputs to ensure it runs efficiently within the given constraints.
- Handle edge cases where the array has fewer than three elements or all elements are identical.
To solve this problem, we will use Python due to its simplicity and efficiency. The main challenge is to efficiently calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean of the remaining elements unchanged. We will use a brute-force approach initially to ensure correctness, and then optimize it for large inputs.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
 # [core concept]
    'mathematical mean': the sum of all elements divided by the number of elements in the array.
    Explanation: The mean (average) of a set of numbers is calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers. In this problem, we need to find pairs of indices [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these indices keeps the mean of the remaining elements equal to the original mean.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'more than': indicates that we need to find pairs where the sum of the elements at the indices is greater than the original mean.
    'at least as many times': means that the number of times the element appears should be at least as much as its value.

# [degree adverb] 
    'largest': indicates that we need to find the largest integer that appears at least as many times as itself.

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    To solve this problem, we need to:
    1. Calculate the original mean of the array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j.
    3. For each pair, calculate the new mean after removing the elements at indices i and j.
    4. Count the number of pairs that result in the new mean being equal to the original mean.

# [edge case] 
    edge case 1: [1, 1, 1] = 1
    Explanation: The array has three elements all equal to 1, so the mean is 1. Deleting any two elements will still leave a mean of 1. The expected output is 1 because there is only one pair [0, 1].

    edge case 2: [2, 2, 4, 4] = 3
    Explanation: The original mean is (2+2+4+4)/4 = 3. Deleting any pair that sums to 6 (e.g., [0, 2] or [1, 3]) will keep the mean at 3. The expected output is 2 because there are two pairs [0, 2] and [1, 3].

    edge case 3: [1, 2, 3, 4] = 2.5
    Explanation: The original mean is (1+2+3+4)/4 = 2.5. Deleting any pair that sums to 3.5 (e.g., [0, 1] or [1, 2]) will keep the mean at 2.5. The expected output is 2 because there are two pairs [0, 1] and [1, 2].

# [extra code for edge case]
    We need extra code to handle the edge cases where the array is too small or all elements are identical.
    For edge case 1:
        if n == 3 and all(x == a[0] for x in a):
            return 1
    For edge case 2 and 3:
        if n == 4 and all(x == a[0] for x in a):
            return 2
    These checks can be added to the initial part of the code to handle edge cases gracefully.

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
 # [core concept]
    'mathematical mean': the sum of all elements divided by the number of elements in the array.
    Explanation: The mean (average) of a set of numbers is calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers. In this problem, we need to find pairs of elements to delete such that the mean of the remaining elements is still equal to the original mean.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'more than': indicates that we need to find pairs where the sum of the elements equals the mean times the number of remaining elements.
    'at least as many times': means that the number of times an element appears should be at least as much as the element itself.

# [degree adverb] 
    'largest': indicates that we need to find the largest integer that appears at least as many times as itself.

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    To implement the solution, we need to:
    1. Calculate the mean of the array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j).
    3. Check if deleting the elements at these positions maintains the mean.
    4. Count the number of such pairs.

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: Array with fewer than three elements.
    search([1, 2]) = 0
    Explanation: With fewer than three elements, it's impossible to delete two elements and still have a mean.

    Edge case 2: All elements in the array are identical.
    search([5, 5, 5]) = 3
    Explanation: There are three pairs [0, 1], [0, 2], and [1, 2] that can be deleted to maintain the mean.

    Edge case 3: No pair can be deleted to maintain the mean.
    search([1, 2, 3]) = 0
    Explanation: There are no pairs that can be deleted to maintain the mean of the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We need extra code to handle the edge case where the array has fewer than three elements.
        if n < 3:
            return 0

examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
